questions.question: She went to the store …………………… bought some pens.
I went to her home, ………………………. she was not there.
questions.description: Use but to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: It is raining, ……………………… we have to cancel the picnic.
questions.description: So shows the effect. Hence is not a conjunction.

questions.question: ………………………… it was snowing, we went out.
questions.description: We use though to connect two contrasting ideas. But goes in the middle of the two clauses connected by it.

questions.question: Will you wait for me ………………………. I finish cooking?
She was upset …………………………. she had failed her exam.
……………………….. I had the money, I could buy a car.
I don’t know ……………………….. I can help or not.
questions.description: Either could be used here however, whether is preferred in a formal style.

questions.question: ………………………… you need help, just give me a call.
questions.description: To express a condition, we use if. As shows the reason.

questions.question: ……………………… it is expensive, I will buy it.
questions.description: Either even if or though is possible here with slightly different meanings.

questions.question: …………………………. we heard the news, we rushed to their home.
…………………………. my friends were there, none of them came forward to help me.
questions.description: Either though or even though is possible here. Even though is a more emphatic form of though.
